pages.title: Wielandiella
pages.text: $(l)Temporal Range:$() Triassic-Jurassic$(br2)$(l)Propagation:$() Use a collection envelope to harvest seeds.$(br2)$(l)Growth:$() Grows on all dirt-like blocks.

In Palaeobotany, names are usually given only to different shapes of fossil. Occasionally an author will want to publish a whole-plant description though, where it has been possible to reconstruct a full plant by close association or preservation complete. Wielandiella is one such taxon.

Wielandiella comprises a full-plant bearing Anomozamites-type leaves, arranged in spiral shoots on woody stems displaying a divaricate branching habit (Y-shaped branching), very like modern Banksia. It bore its flower and seed cone at the tips of shoots, which then branched below the cone. Bennettites were not Angiosperms,

but are known to have usually produced sometimes dramatic flower-like or cone-like structures for pollination and seed production, and so we have added the suggestion of floral structures to our plant. Bennettites leaves are usually somewhat thickly-textured, not delicate, and so we assume the plants were somewhat tough and resilient,

able to grow in many different types of habitat, and their dominance of Mesozoic floras backs this up.$(br2)The various discoveries which can be reconstructed as Wielandiella have been found in fossil layers dating from the Late Triassic to the Mid Jurassic, typically in the northern hemisphere.

Various subtle differences in stem and leaf have led to a few different species being proposed for Wielandiella plants. None bore very large examples of the Anomozamites leaves, and the stems are typically narrow, suggesting a smallish shrubby-growth.
